title: Why your dentist is worried about the world
text:
From the gig economy to climate anxiety, the stress of modern life is showing up in our teeth.

On a recent visit to my dentist, our conversation turned serious. “People are so tense these days,” David told me as he tested the drill as though just back from Guantanamo Bay.

Unable to speak, and feeling a little tense myself, I motioned he should continue with his pop psychology lecture, as it was better than listening to years of caffeine and nicotine being removed. Don’t judge – in China, smoking was the healthy option.

Wage Slave's dentist says he's seeing a lot more patients plagued by anxiety. Erin Jonasson

While complimenting me on my oral health, if not my life choices, he said plaque was not really a problem these days. The real problem, according to Dave, is chipped teeth caused by anxious wage slaves grinding away at their work stations while pretending to “crush it”.

“I used to see only one or two cases of chipped teeth a year,” he said. “Now it’s three or four every month, and often it’s younger people.” After mentioning that he was off to Berlin for a month, David concluded that “work stress” or “job anxiety” was one cause of this newest of First-World problems.

He may be right. Australia’s foremost expert in this field (OK, the only guy I know in the area), Professor Mark Wooden from Melbourne University, released a paper in April in which he largely concurred with David’s thesis.
description: From the gig economy to climate anxiety, the stress of modern life is showing up in our teeth.
